column4: Hi guys - trying to mount an NFS share with pretty default values - get "mount(2) invalid argument"
mount.nfs: mount(2): Invalid argument
mount.nfs: an incorrect mount option was specified
what are you actually typing?
hmm... try dropping final '/' in the paths?
no dice
does it work if you don't pass "-t nfs" explicitly?
no - nor if I run mount.nfs
with -v, the full output is just that one line "mount(2) invalid argument"?
https://gist.github.com/c85b36ce04ccac505b8f
looks like http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=568288, there's a workaround with adding -o nfsversionblahblah in there
adding "-o nfsvers-3" or "-o nfsvers-4" doesn't help
it is correctly parsed though because -v displays it
not sure if you missed it, you need to use nfsvers=3, not nfsvers-3
that certainly does give a different error...
ha
Humiliation. 1. /etc/hosts.allow on the server wasn't configured with the host.  2. had to force version 3 - even though the other client doesn't require that.
but - original client is Ubuntu 10.04 and new client is 10.10
so - the default must have changed.
thanks for your help
maybe default nfs version changed
I guess it must have.
